title: Did the Ancient Persians adopt the Sumerian Cuneiform (writing system) since Old Persian writing was invented 2,000+ years after Cuneiform and looks similar to it? - Quora

response.answer_text: The cuneiform used for writing Old Persian was definitely inspired by the Sumerian one, but there’s no proof that it derived from it directly, given that they don’t share any symbols with one another - although the script itself was fairly close to the cuneiform that both Akkadian and Elamite used, the difference being that the former two were more likely syllabic, while Old Persian was closer to an alphabet.  (source)  (source) So no, Persians didn’t adopt the Sumerian cuneiform for writing the earliest stage of Persian, but the writing system which was made for the language was inspired by the Sumerian cuneiform. Same goes for Elamite, although it did directly derive from the Akkado-Sumerian cuneiform, as far as the script is concerned (just to be clear that I’m not talking about the language itself).
